newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: EU leaders to look at human cloning ban.
newsitem.headline: EU leaders to look at human cloning ban.

text.p: European Union leaders said on Wednesday they recognised the importance of research into genetic cloning but would look at ways to prevent the technique being used on humans.

A declaration issued at the end of a two-day summit in Amsterdam, which agreed a new EU treaty, asked EU ministers and the European Commission "to examine how to prevent human cloning" when defining policy on research and patents and when implementing existing programmes.
The leaders also stressed the "willingness of member states to take...all necessary measures to ban human cloning."

While recognising the "great importance" of genetic research, they said "the protection of human beings and the respect of their integrity" were fundamental principles which also had to be taken into consideration.

The Commission already said late last month that it was studying whether to propose a formal ban on cloning humans. Commission President Jacques Santer said then that EU rules should explicitly exclude human cloning from patent protection.

That followed a report by an EU advisory group on biotechnology ethics which called for a ban on "reproductive" human cloning -- creating a genetically identical human being using cells from a child or adult -- saying the technique was "ethically unacceptable" and a safety threat.

The possibility of human cloning has taken on a more realistic dimension since scientists in Scotland, working with the biotechnology company PPL Therapeutics Plc, cloned a sheep known as Dolly from a single cell of another sheep.

Europe is not alone with its concerns, and U.S. President Bill Clinton on Monday proposed a five-year ban on cloning a human being, saying it was morally unacceptable and could undermine society's respect for human life.
Wednesday's EU declaration said the EU leaders would show "increased vigilance" regarding the ethical risks of genetic cloning, but gave no specific views on the use of the technique on animals.

The EU's Group of Advisers on the Ethical Implications of Biotechnology -- made up of outside scientific, legal and ethical experts -- said cloning of farm animals could have medical, agricultural and economic benefits.
